entry.title: USAID chief joins US officials calling on Azerbaijan to lift Karabakh blockade

media:group.media:title: USAID chief joins US officials calling on Azerbaijan to lift Karabakh blockade
media:group.media:description:
üìçSamantha Power, the head of USAID, called on Azerbaijan to lift its blockade of Karabakh. üìçLouis Bono, Washington‚Äôs special representative to the South Caucasus, will visit the region later this week. üìçThe European Court of Human Rights gave Azerbaijan one week to provide information on the health of the Karabakh resident who was detained over the weekend during a medical evacuation. üìçTurkey‚Äôs support for Azerbaijan during the 2020 Nagorno-Karabakh war played a key role in Armenia‚Äôs defeat, former Defense Minister Davit Tonoyan said.

entry.title: ‚ÄúMy children will soon know what starvation is‚Äù: Humanitarian crisis deepens in Karabakh

media:group.media:title: ‚ÄúMy children will soon know what starvation is‚Äù: Humanitarian crisis deepens in Karabakh
media:group.media:description:
Out of 120,000 people living under Azerbaijani blockade in Nagorno-Karabakh for more than seven months, 30,000 are children. Today, amid growing shortages of food, fuel and essential goods, children are one of the most vulnerable populations in the region. Cases of malnutrition are on the rise, baby food and formula milk are almost gone, and medicines are quickly running out. No food, medicine or humanitarian aid has entered the region in more than a month, while officials warn of an imminent threat of starvation.

media:group.media:title: Despair is not for Armenians
media:group.media:description:
Garo Ghazarian sits down with Lara Tcholakian to share his purpose and life mission, his perseverance for the rights of Armenians, and his drive as imprinted by his parents and ancestors since the Armenian genocide. Ghazarian shares his story of how he was raised and educated in Lebanon by parents (Barkev Ghazarian and Ovsanna Poladian) and grandparents, from Kaladuran, Kessab. He describes the role that his family has played in instilling the values and qualities he acquired, his sources of motivation, and the importance of working to advance the Armenian cause. Ghazarian expresses his thoughts on the importance of continuing to battle and face the challenges that the Armenian people face, in Artsakh, Armenia, Jerusalem and wherever there is a need.
About Garo Ghazarian Garo Ghazarian is a Criminal Defense Lawyer. He is the former Dean of the People‚Äôs College of Law and a law professor in various universities and academies in the US, Armenia and Artsakh. He is regularly invited to speak on CNN, Fox, and Al-Jazeera English TV. He serves on numerous community boards and is a memberof the City of Glendale Civil Service Commission, where he has also been Chairman. He served as Chairman of the Armenian Bar Association for two terms and board member (and Co-Chair) of the Armenian Rights Watch Committee. He has been a recipient of various awards for his community service and work for the Armenian cause. Since the Artsakh War in 2020, he has increasingly cooperated and assisted the Human Rights Defenders of Armenia and of Artsakh and has co-founded and co-hosted FRONTLINES-LIVE on CivilNet.
Program overview In a new open setting, Lara deconstructs inherited cultural and historical narratives, memories, life lessons and experiences from change catalysts. Her guests reflect on the stories, people, events and mindsets that have shaped their professional and personal lives, enabling them to create a more mindful life.
#CivilNet #mindfulleaders #inheritedlegacies

entry.title: How Armenian women are shaping tech

media:group.media:title: How Armenian women are shaping tech
media:group.media:description:
Armenia's booming IT sector is rapidly expanding, attracting global tech giants and exporting to a global market. The second annual FemInno Conference took place July 29-30 to promote talent in business, science, and technology. Data from the Statistical Committee of the Republic of Armenia states that 30%-40% of IT employees in Armenia are women. This conference aims to raise awareness about local professionals to the international community. We spoke to some of the guest speakers at the event to understand what inspired them most about Armenia.

entry.title: Azerbaijan pulls out of planned Karabakh talks in Slovakia

media:group.media:title: Azerbaijan pulls out of planned Karabakh talks in Slovakia
media:group.media:description:
üìçAzerbaijan pulled out of planned talks with Karabakh officials in Slovakia, according to a senior Karabakh official. üìçU.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken spoke by phone with Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev to call for the restoration of transit along the Lachin corridor. üìçVagif Khachatryan, the seriously ill Karabakh resident detained by Azerbaijani border guards during a Red Cross medical evacuation, remains in custody in Baku. üìçArmenia‚Äôs freestyle wrestling team swept the competition at this year‚Äôs Francophone games, with all five team members taking home medals.

entry.title: Establishing three bio research centers in Armenia

media:group.media:title: Establishing three bio research centers in Armenia
media:group.media:description:
Diane Barber, Professor in the Department of Cell and Tissue Biology at the University of California, San Francisco, sat down with CivilNet on the sidelines of the Armenian Society of Fellows conference in Dilijan, Armenia, to discuss plans to establish three research corps in Armenia. Her research has focused partly on cell behaviours, and has given insight into the various processes pertaining to cancer cells and stem cells. According to Barber, there is plenty of talent among young Armenian students, but the technologies, infrastructure and facilities are not up to international standards. Barber explains how exactly these new corps will allow Armenian students and researchers to reach their full potential and tap into new opportunities.

entry.title: Russian and Iranian artists find community in a remote Armenian town

media:group.media:title: Russian and Iranian artists find community in a remote Armenian town
media:group.media:description:
Tumanyan is a town nestled in the Debed Canyon, in Armenia‚Äôs northern Lori region. In recent months, it has become a place of refuge and an opportunity for artistic expression for participants of the Abastan program. What started as an initiative for Russian migrants turned into a community of international artists. This video is about the life of artists in Abastan, what precarious situations they have escaped from, and how the space serves as a place of refuge.
